title: Proactive Information Retrieval by User Modeling from Eye Tracking
segmentation: Yeah, so I'm from Helsinki, University of Technology and I'm going to talk about proactive information retrieval and eye tracking or measuring eye movements so.
When people are very good at inferring things from days, we will, we can say from how people look and where people look something about what's going on in their minds.
But of course the computers can't do that because they don't have any eyes, so they can't infer anything.
So they are quite clumsy in that respect.
They have to make do with what people type in and use mouse, and so and so it's, well, it's a hot task for computers, of course.
And this practice interviews are interfaces.
So the idea is if we could anticipate or guess what people want, we could do some things already in the background and make better results in.
For example, in information retrieval.
If we have an inkling of what people want or what their mental state is, where we could make things a lot easier.
People don't have to be so specific about things when they want to find find some.
To some queries and so on.

We have something like we have reading and then we have visual search where we try to find some keywords from the text and so on.

They handled the same topic as the question.
So to make it a bit more difficult and then.

The task of the of the participants was to read the list of titles and then find the correct answer and then give, give, give us the answer and well, we measure at the eye movements and then try to predict the correct answer from the eye movements and well as a surprise.
